children.name: a person or place that is attacked
victim
children.definition: /ˈvɪktɪm, ˈvɪktəm/  sb who has been attacked:nạn nhân
examples: The victim was shaken, but physically unharmed.
victim of
She had been the victim of a particularly vicious attack.
The children are the innocent/helpless victimsofthe fighting.
the child/ elderlyvictims of the war.

children.name: target
children.definition: /ˈtɑːʳgɪt, ˈtɑːʳgət/  a person or place that sb, especially a military group, has chosen to attack: mục tiêu tấn công
examples: The bomb missed its target by several kilometres.
prime target(very obvious and probable target)
Holding a US passport makes these tourists a prime target for terrorists
military/civilian target
The GIA continued its attacks on civilian targets.
target of
The Institution has been the target of terrorist attack several times.
The commonly used roads are the targets of heavy fire.
target zone/area
When the plane gets to the target area, it drops the missile and returns to base.

children.name: under attack
children.definition: if an army or place is under attack, it is being attacked :bị tấn công
examples: The rebels are under attack and may surrender at any time.
under attack from
At first, he thought the Pacific Fleet was under attack from German forces.
come under attack/begin to be attacked :
We were united by a sense of national pride when our country came under attack.

children.name: ambush
children.definition: /ˈæmbʊʃ/  if a group of people ambush someone, they hide and wait for them and then suddenly attack them : phục kích, đánh du kích
examples: The rebel group successfully ambushed a regiment of American reinforcements.
He was afraid he would be stopped by government troops or, even worse, ambushed by the Vietcong.
Parker ambushed a school bus on a field trip and held 17 children and their teacher hostage.

children.name: a country that attacks another country
aggressor
children.definition: /əˈgresəʳ/  a country that attacks another country, especially when that country has not already attacked first: quân xâm lược
examples: The situation is complex and it is not easy to determine exactly who is the aggressor in this case.
military/foreign etc aggressor
a call for united action against the foreign aggressor
The USSR scored valuable propaganda points against its Western aggressors.

children.name: occupy
children.definition: (of an army or group of people) to move into and take control and/or possession of a place : chiếm đóng, chiếm lĩnh, chiếm cứ
examples: Troops quickly occupied the city.
Protesting students occupied the university office for two weeks.
the occupying forces
occupation[U noun] [C2] when an army or group of people moves into and takes control of a place : sự chiếm giữ, sự chiếm đóng
Do you support U.S. military occupation and for how long?’
occupation of
the Italian occupationofEthiopia

children.name: attack
children.definition: /əˈtæk/  to attack a place or country using weapons, aircraft, soldiers etc : tấn công
examples: On 25 April, British and Australian troops attacked the enemy at Gallipoli.
The village had been attacked by enemy warplanes.
The special unit attacked at dawn, inflicting heavy losses.
General Powell consulted with the President before giving the order to attack.
attacking[attri adj] tấn công
attacking army/forces :quân đội/ lực lượng tấn công
Almost two-thirds of the attacking force had been wiped out.

children.name: invade
children.definition: /ɪnˈveɪd/  if a country’s army invades another country, it enters it and tries to control it : xâm chiếm, xâm lược
examples: Enemy forces were almost certainly preparing to invade.
Sicily was invaded by the Normans, and later by the Saracens.
In his latest film, super-intelligent aliens invade Earth and try to take over.
invading[attri adj]
invading army/forces etc : quân xâm lược
The villagers headed for the mountains to escape the invading army.

children.name: raid
children.definition: /reɪd/  if a group of soldiers raids a place or town belonging to an enemy, they attack it suddenly and without any warning and cause a lot of damage in a short time:
examples: công kích, đột kích
The rebels raided the tiny mountain town early on Tuesday.
Again, the tribe had raided a neighbouring village, inflicting many casualties.

children.name: launch an attack
children.definition: launch/ mount an attack to start to attack an enemy’s army, country, or property, in a planned way : mở, tiến hành một cuộc tấn công
examples: A fresh attack was mounted on the last remaining rebels.

children.name: storm
children.definition: /stɔːʳm/  to suddenly attack a city or building that is well-defended by getting inside it and taking control : đột chiếm
examples: Heavily armed and masked gunmen stormed an ammunitions store in Co. Mayo.
An attempt by government forces to storm the hijacked airplane

children.name: besiege
children.definition: /bɪˈsiːdʒ/  to surround a city or building with soldiers in order to stop the people inside from getting out or from receiving supplies such as food and water : bao vây
examples: The capital has been besieged by the opposition militia for two months now.
Federal agents besieged the compound in Waco in 1993.
besieged[attri adj]
besieged city/town/castle etc
Hundreds of Serbs managed to flee the besieged city.

children.name: launch an invasion
children.definition: launch/ mount an invasion to start to attack an enemy’s army, country, or property, in a planned way : mở, tiến hành một cuộc xâm lược
examples: The Huns, normally a peaceful race, launched an invasion into Europe via the Caspian Steppes.

children.name: attack
children.definition: /əˈtæk/  when a military force attacks a place or country, using weapons, aircraft, soldiers etc: cuộc tấn công
examples: The attack began at dawn.
The caller warned that the attacks will continue until the demands are met.
attack on
missile attacks on civilian targets
tấn công tên lửa vào các mục tiêu dân sự
naval/air/artillery/terrorist etc attack
The city is exposed and vulnerable to air attack.
Eleven people were injured in a rocket attack on Sunday night.
go on the attackstart to attack someone or something :
To my horror, the soldiers went on the attack, killing men, women and children indiscriminately.
These bomb blasts suggest that the terroristsare(going) on theattack (= trying to defeat or hurt other people) again.

children.name: invasion
children.definition: /ɪnˈveɪʒən/  when an army from one country enters another country and tries to control it : cuộc xâm lược
examples: The fear of an invasion by rebels is always present.
foreign/military etc invasion
Some analysts fear that increasing desperation could lead to a military invasion of the country’s southern neighbors.
the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia
invasion of
They were planning to mount an invasionofthe north of the country.

children.name: raid
children.definition: /reɪd/  a short quick attack by a group of soldiers, planes, or ships on a place that belongs to an enemy : cuộc đột kích
examples: military/bombing/aerial etc raid
He led a commando raid in the desert.
a surprise raid
NATO bombing raids
air raid(one carried out by planes dropping bombs)
Some of the most beautiful architecture in the city was destroyed in the air raids.
air-raid sirens
raid on/against
Sixty people are thought to have been killed in the raid on the village just west of the capital.
John Brown’s raid on Harper’s Ferry
As a teenager, he was involved in a raid against a village of Omaha Indians.
made/ staged/ carried out a raid:
The commandosmade/staged/carried outa daring raid onthe enemy.

children.name: ambush
children.definition: /ˈæmbʊʃ/  a sudden attack by a group of soldiers who have been hiding and waiting for someone : cuộc phục kích
examples: killed/shot etc in an ambush
Six or seven of the passengers were killed in an ambush on the narrowest part of the road.
lie/wait in ambushwait in order to ambush :
They moved slowly, knowing that in the next clump of trees enemy soldiers might be lying in ambush.

children.name: assault
children.definition: /əˈsɔːlt/  a military attack to take control of a place controlled by the enemy: cuộc công kích
examples: aerial/military/naval etc assault :
a massive armed assault on the city
assault on/against
Only a successful assault on the rebels’ headquarters could have ended the civil war.

children.name: strike
children.definition: /straɪk/  a sudden attack, especially one from the air, using bombs: công kích
examples: The rebels launched a retaliatory strike.
air/nuclear/missile etc strike :
The bomb strike took place on a camp near Krek.
nuclear strike capability

children.name: offensive
children.definition: /əˈfensɪv/  a planned attack involving large forces and often taking place over several weeks or months, especially as part of a plan to win a war : cuộc chiến
examples: military/nuclear/air etc offensive
The great military offensive had failed, and it seemed victory was escaping them.
The rebel offensive resumed on Thursday, leaving 12 dead and many injured.
offensive on/against : cuộc chiến vào , chống lại
The President announced a counter-offensive on the rebels.
launch/mount an offensive
Government troops launched an offensive against UNITA positions in the north.

children.name: aggression
children.definition: /əˈgreʃən/  the act of attacking a country, especially when that country has not attacked first-used especially in political contexts:khai chiến, xâm chiếm
examples: The invasion was condemned as ‘blatant aggression’ by the British Prime Minister.
The President promised to use all his powers to prevent further aggression.
armed/foreign/military etc agression
another example of communist aggression
aggression against
As our older generation knows from experience, unchecked aggression against a small nation is a prelude to international disaster.
an act of aggression
Any eastward expansion would be regarded by the government as an act of aggression.

children.name: attack sb because they attacked you
retaliate
children.definition: /rɪˈtælieɪt/  to attack someone because they have attacked you first:
examples: trả thù , trả đũa
▪ The government wants peace, but will not hesitate to retaliate if attacked.
chính phủ muốn hòa bình , nhưng sẽ không ngần ngại trả đũa nếu bị tấn công
▪ She decided not to retaliate physically, because it would put her in even greater danger.
cô ấy quyết định không trả đũa về thể xác , bởi vì nó sẽ gây nguy hiểm cho cô hơn
retaliate by doing something : trả đữa bằng cách làm gì
▪ When police tried to push back the crowd, a few youths retaliated by throwing stones at them.
khi cảnh sát cố gắng đẩy đám đông , một vài thanh niên đã trả đũa bằng cách ném đá vào họ
▪ Later that day, whites retaliated by killing a young black delivery driver.
ngày hôm đó, người da trắng trả đũa bằng cách giết chết một lái xe giao hàng trẻ màu đen
retaliate against : trả đũa
▪ He has promised to take tough measures to retaliate against extremists.
ông đã hứa sẽ có những biện pháp cứng rắn để tra đũa những kẻ cực đoan
retaliate for : because of what someone has done to you
trả đũa việc gì (vì những gì người khác làm cho bạn )
▪ In an interview, Tyson claimed he was retaliating for Holyfield’s attack on him.
trong một cuộc phỏng vấn , Tyson tuyên bố anh ta trả đũa cuộc tấn công của Holyfield vào anh ta
retaliate with : trả đũa bằng
▪ I fully accept that it was wrong of the guards to retaliate with blows and kicks.
tôi hoàn toàn chấp nhận rằng các vệ sĩ đã sai lầm khi trả đũa bằng cú đánh và đá
retaliation/rɪˌtæliˈeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]sựtrả đũa
▪ America stopped short of military retaliation, but issued a strong statement condemning the invasion.
hoa kỳ không còn trả thù quân sự nữa, nhưng đã đưa ra tuyên bố mạnh mẽ lên án cuộc xâm lăng
▪ the threat of retaliation :
đe dọa trả đũa
in retaliation (for something) : để trã đũa cái gì
▪ They plotted the attack in retaliation for the attack by federal agents on the camp.
họ đã lên kế hoạch tấn công để trả đũa các cuộc tấn công của các nhân viên liêng bang trong trại
▪ Three inmates were killed in retaliation.
ba tù nhân đã bị giết trong cuộc trả đũa

children.name: counter-attack
children.definition: phản công
examples: Once the harvest was in, the peasants were free to counter-attack
counter-attack/ˈkaʊntərəˌtæk/ [C noun] an attack that an army makes after it has been attacked by an enemy :cuộc phản công
The enemy had started a vicious counter-attack, forcing the French into the woods.
launch/mount a counter-attack : thực hiện một cuộc tấn công
Allied forces were regrouping in order to launch a counter-attack.

children.name: hit back
children.definition: / strike back to attack a person or army that has attacked you first, especially in order to try and show that you are very strong and cannot be defeated:phản công (để thị uy sức mạnh)
examples: The tanks and artillery will hit back hard if the ceasefire is broken.
hit back/strike back with :
Less than 24 hours after this cross-border raid, army jets hit back with a devastating air strike.
hit back/strike back at :
He suspected that the US would take the opportunity to strike back at the Axis forces.

children.name: tit-for-tat
children.definition: /ˌtɪt fəʳ ˈtæt/  tit-for-tatkillings/murders/response etc: a killing, reaction etc done because someone has done something similar to someone in your group:ăn miếng trả miếng
examples: Any hope of peace is destroyed by these endless tit-for-tat attacks.
The murder is thought to have been a tit-for-tat response by the Mafia to an earlier gangland killing.
